STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 15, 2020
Jennifer Stevens
Samaritas - MID MI
Ste 200
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49201
RE: License #: CB380201255
Samaritas - MID MI
Ste 200
729 W. Michigan Ave.
Jackson, MI 49201
Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
June 3, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the
MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 For repeat violation, why the prior CAPs failed to achieve compliance.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If
you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Claudia Triestram, at (269) 337-5289.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Stephanie Meeuwenberg, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
121 Franklin St. SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(616) 414-2982
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12209 Orientation and training.
(1) An agency shall ensure and document that each social
service worker and each social service supervisor receives not
less than 16 hours of orientation after initial appointment and
before assumption of assigned duties.
One of nine new employees did not have orientation prior to assumption of assigned
duties.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
One of nine new employees did not have a written evaluation within the six-month
required timeframe.
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(b) A copy of the job description for the staff member's
current position.
One of nine new employees did not have a copy of the job description signed prior to
assumption of job duties.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
4

(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
(ii) A dental reexamination shall be obtained at least every
18 months, unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight foster care files and one of three independent living files reviewed did
not have verification of a dental exam being done within the last 12 months.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of eight current foster care files contained untimely updated service plans.
This is a repeat noncompliance, Interim Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding
CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must report why the previous CAP failed and how
they will ensure compliance.
R 400.12422 Foster care record
(3) The record shall contain all of the following information: (e)
Change of placement documentation as required by R
400.12405.
One of eight current foster care files, one of four closed foster care files, and one of
two closed independent living files were missing documentation as required in the
DHHS 69. This is a repeat noncompliance, Interim Report, 9/4/19, and
corresponding CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must report why the previous CAP
failed and how they will ensure compliance. This was also designated as a
repeat noncompliance in the Renewal Report dated 7/16/18, and corresponding
CAP, dated 7/30/18. This is the 5th consecutive year this has been a violation.
The agency must report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure
compliance.
R 400.12403 Policy and procedures
(2) The policies and procedures shall cover at least all of the
following areas:
(i) Service plans.
Five of eight foster care files were found non complaint with obtaining signatures on
the plans. One of seven applicable files obtained an untimely parental signature. Four
of seven applicable files were found to have missing and/or late caregiver signatures.
5

This is a repeat noncompliance, Interim Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding
CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must report why the previous CAP failed and how
they will ensure compliance. This was also designated as a repeat
noncompliance in the Renewal Report dated 7/16/18, and corresponding CAP,
dated 7/30/18. This is the 5th consecutive year this has been a violation. The
agency must report why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure
compliance.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be included in section
1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements
except for the following:
DHHS Policy FOM 801 – page 11-13 Medical Passports
Four of eight foster care files and one of three independent living files reviewed
were found to have late and/or missing medical passports. This is a repeat
noncompliance, Interim Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding CAP, 9/19/19. The
agency must report why the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure
compliance. This was also designated as a repeat noncompliance in the
Renewal Report dated 7/16/18, and corresponding CAP, dated 7/30/18. This
is the 5th consecutive year this has been a violation. The agency must report
why the previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy - FOM 722-06H Page 1-3 – Overview and quality visit
standards
Three of eight current foster care files were observed to have social work contacts
for home visits that simply noted a visit was completed without providing the
required information for a quality visit. This is a repeat noncompliance, Interim
Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must report why
the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H - Page 5 – Caseworker contact child in out -of-
home Placement
One of eight applicable foster care files reviewed were found to have missed a
face to face contact with the child. This is a repeat noncompliance, Interim
Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must report why
the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance. This was also
6

designated as a repeat noncompliance in the Renewal Report dated 7/16/18,
and corresponding CAP, dated 7/30/18. This is the 5th consecutive year this
has been a violation. The agency must report why the previous CAPs failed
and how they will ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy 722-06B - page 2-6 - Family Team Meetings.
Six of eight current foster care files and one of three independent living files
reviewed were found to have missing and/or late FTMs and semiannual meetings.
This includes FTMs that were done for a quarterly up/case service planning but
were not within 30 days of the plan being due. This is a repeat noncompliance,
Interim Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must
report why the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
This was also designated as a repeat noncompliance in the Renewal Report
dated 7/16/18, and corresponding CAP, dated 7/30/18. This is the 5th
consecutive year this has been a violation. The agency must report why the
previous CAPs failed and how they will ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-06H p 15 Timely entry of caseworker contacts
Three of eight foster care files were found to have entered multiple social work
contacts beyond the 5 days permitted. This is a repeat noncompliance, Interim
Report, 9/4/19, and corresponding CAP, 9/19/19. The agency must report why
the previous CAP failed and how they will ensure compliance.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-08 page 22 Initial Service Plan
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One of one initial service plan reviewed was
submitted late.
DHHS Policy FOM 722-09 page 25-26 Updated Service Plan
Eight foster care files were reviewed. Three of twenty-six updated service plans
reviewed were submitted late.
DHHS Policy FOM 801 page 17 Health services for children in foster care
One of eight foster care files reviewed was missing the DHHS-3762, Consent to
Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Treatment card.
7

DHHS Policy FOM 722-03E page 2 Placement exception requests and
approvals
Eight foster care files were reviewed. One of six applicable files was missing the
placement exception request for sibling placed apart.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency was advised to use the MiSACWIS job aide when uploading
documents and ensure they are being uploaded in the correct area.
 The agency was advised to be consistent in labeling documents they are
uploading as many things were not clearly labeled and difficult to locate in the
Document section of MiSACWIS.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not request consultation for this period under review.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. This CAP, dated 9/19/19, was submitted in
response to their interim inspection. The agency has several repeat violations
throughout the period under review and therefore their prior CAP has not been
completely successful and the agency will need to review their processes and
address reasons for prior CAP failures.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
8

Stephanie Meeuwenberg Date
